metadata.titleEn: Glacier coverage data on the Tibetan Plateau in 2017 (TPG2017, Version1.0)
metadata.description: The Tibetan Plateau Glacier Data –TPG2017 is a glacial coverage data on the Tibetan Plateau from selected 210 scenes of Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI) images with 30-m spatial resolution from 2013 to 2018, among of which 90% was in 2017 and 85% in winter. Therefore, 2017 was defined as the reference year for the mosaic image. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the 2017 image mosaic, relying on false-colour image composites (RGB by bands 654), which allowed us to distinguish ice/snow from cloud. Debris-free ice was distinguished from the debris and debris-covered ice by its higher reflectance. Debris-covered ice was not delineated in this data. The delineated glacier outlines were compared with band-ratio (e.g. TM3/TM5) results, and validated by overlapping them onto Google Earth imagery, SRTM DEM, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images. For areas with mountain shadows and snow cover, they were verified by different methods using data from different seasons. For glaciers in deep shadow, Google EarthTM imagery from different dates was used as the reference for manual delineation. Steep slopes or headwalls were also excluded in the TPG2017. Areas that appeared in any of these sources to have the characteristics of exposed ground/basement/bed rock were manually delineated as non-glacier, and were also cross-checked with CGI-1 and CGI-2. Steep hanging glaciers were included in TPG2017 if they were identifiable on images in all other three epochs (i.e. TPG1976, TPG2001, and TPG2013). The accuracy of manual digitization was controlled within one half-pixel. All glacier areas were calculated on the WGS84 spheroid in an Albers equal-area map projection centred at (95°E, 30°N) with standard parallels at 15°N and 65°N. Our results showed that the relative deviation of manual interpretation was less than 3.9%.
metadata.instructions:
The name of the data file is tpg2017data.
This data is in raster tiff format, which can be used in geographic information system software such as ArcMap.

background: Nearly all mountain glaciers have been melting rapidly in recent decades (Gardner and others, 2013; Zemp and others, 2015) and this has been documented, especially in High Mountain Asia (HMA hereafter), in surveys of the whole (Li and others, 2008; Cogley, 2016) or large parts (Bolch and others, 2012; Yao and others, 2012) of the region as well as in basin-scale and single-glacier studies (Fujita and Nuimura, 2011; Wang and others, 2013; Yang and others, 2013). As reported in these earlier studies, most HMA glaciers showed obvious shrinkage (area loss) and thinning (implying mass loss) except in the west, for example in the Karakoram (Gardelle and others, 2012) and western Kunlun (Neckel and others, 2014; Kääb and others, 2015; Ke and others, 2015). However, due to strong spatiotemporal differences of climate variability and topographic effects, the magnitudes of glacier shrinkage have varied in space and time. The TP, defined by outlines from Zhang and others (2014), can be divided into two categories of hydrological unit, the outlines and basin codes of which we take from Shi and others (2008). Generally, meltwater from glaciers in IB flows into inland depressions, while those in EC flow into the ocean and so contribute more directly to sea-level rise. Climatically, the Indian monsoon dominates in the southeastern TP in summer (e.g. in 5O, 5N, 5L), with some effects from the East Asian monsoon in the east (e.g. in 5Y4, 5J, 5K). The westerlies are dominant in winter, especially in the western TP (e.g. 5Y6, 5Z4, 5Z3). Regions in the interior TP, such as 5Z1, 5Z2, 5Z5, 5Z6 and 5Y5 are less influenced both by the summer monsoon and the westerlies (Yao and others, 2012).
research objective: In this study, we present debris-free glacier area changes and their spatial heterogeneity at the plateau scale from the 1970s to 2013 based on three mosaic Landsat images, i.e. in the 1970s (TPG1970s), TPG2001 and TPG2013. Another purpose of the study is to enrich the available collection of glacier inventories in HMA, by presenting a detailed comparison of TPG datasets with previous glacier inventories.
challenges: We were unable to remove debris-covered areas from the GAMDAM inventory (GGI) (Nuimura and others, 2015), which includes debris cover but does not distinguish it from debris-free ice. Obviously snow and clouds could have affected glacier delineation, especially in southeastern Tibet where cloudy days are rather frequent in every season. Nor is it likely that the area differences are due to different treatment of debris cover, which is omitted in TGP2001 and included in GAMDAM.
methods: Glacier outlines (TPG1976, TPG2001 and TPG2013) were digitized manually with guidance from the SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. To achieve complete multi-temporal coverage in a reasonable time, only debris-free ice was delineated. Time series of Landsat scenes were processed with Standard Terrain Correction (Level 1T), which provided systematic radiometric and geometric accuracy by incorporating ground control points while employing SRTM DEM for topographic accuracy. High-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage were selected for the delineation of glaciers. Glacier outlines were digitized on-screen manually from the three image mosaics, relying on false-colour image composites (MSS: red, green and blue (RGB) represented by bands 321; TM/ETM+: RGB by bands 543, OLI: RGB by bands 654), which allowed us to distinguish ice and snow from cloud. The manual delineation was carried out by three operators over a period of 6 years. The delineated glacier outlines were validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps and corresponding satellite images by another two glacier researchers with field survey experience.
dataset: Glacier area on the plateau decreased from 44 366 ± 2827 km2 (1.7% of the study area) in the 1970s to 42 210 ± 1621 km2 in 2001 and 41 137 ± 1616 km2 in 2013.
findings: The comparative analysis of three mosaics shows that glacier area loss across the entire Tibetan Plateau is unequivocal. The glaciers in the M1970-76 subset showed shrinkage at−0.19% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.20% a−1 during 2001– 13. Glaciers in the M1970-88 subset shrank at −0.34% a−1 during 1988 – 2013, and in the M1970-94 subset at −0.42% a−1 during 1994– 2013. The most dramatic glacier shrinkage occurred in the Mekong basin (region 5L) in the southeast, with change rates for M1970s-76 glaciers of −0.43% a−1 during 1976 – 2013 (−0.31% a−1 during 1976– 2001 and −0.73% a−1 during 2001– 13). Glaciers in the western and northern Tibetan Plateau changed at the slowest rates: −0.12% a−1 in 5Y6, −0.14% a−1 in 5Z1, −0.17% a−1 in 5Y5 and −0.17% a−1 in 5Z5 from 1976 to 2013. Overall, glaciers in externally drained catchments showed more dramatic shrinkage than those in the internally drained catchments. This shows a spatial gradient across the plateau of glacier shrinkage rate, decreasing from the southeast to the north and the west.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of distinguishing between debris-covered and debris-free glacier areas?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method addressing this challenge involves the use of manual digitization of glacier outlines with guidance from SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, where only debris-free ice was delineated. This approach helped to achieve complete multi-temporal coverage in a reasonable time.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge in data collection when using satellite imagery for glacier monitoring in regions with frequent cloud cover?
Example.Answer: A challenge in data collection using satellite imagery for glacier monitoring in cloudy regions, such as southeastern Tibet, includes the difficulty in delineating glaciers due to snow and cloud coverage, which affects the accuracy of glacier outlines.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that illustrates the spatial heterogeneity of glacier changes across the Tibetan Plateau over several decades?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the glacier area dataset that shows a decrease from 44,366 ± 2,827 km2 in the 1970s to 42,210 ± 1,621 km2 in 2001 and 41,137 ± 1,616 km2 in 2013, illustrating the spatial heterogeneity of glacier changes across the Tibetan Plateau.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of glacier data derived from multi-spectral remote sensing?
Feature Specification.Answer: net glacier coverage areas without debris, TIFF format, 30m grid unit, Albers equal-area conic projection, false-color composite images (RGB:654), manually digitized glacier outlines, boundary digitization precision of half a pixel (15m)

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are faced when delineating glacier boundaries using remote sensing data?
Feature Specification.Answer: distinguishing debris-covered areas, removing seasonal snow and shadows, dealing with cloud coverage, manual digitization, validation by multiple operators using various reference data

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of glaciers can be measured and analyzed to assess their changes over time?
Feature Specification.Answer: glacier area changes, spatial heterogeneity of glacier shrinkage, rate of glacier area loss over different time periods

Quantification.Question: What is the grid cell size used in the glacier dataset for the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What does 'manual digitization of glacier outlines' entail in remote sensing data processing?
Definition.Answer: Manual digitization of glacier outlines involves manually tracing the boundaries of glaciers on satellite imagery. This process is typically guided by auxiliary datasets such as digital elevation models (DEMs) and involves human operators who use tools to create vector representations of glacier extents. It is a precise method that allows researchers to differentiate ice and snow from other features like clouds.

Comparison.Question: How do manual digitization methods using Landsat imagery compare to automated systems in terms of accuracy and applicability for glacier delineation on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Manual digitization methods allow for high accuracy, as demonstrated by the digitization precision of half a pixel (15m), and involve expert validation across multiple datasets such as SRTM DEM and Google Earth. This method also allows for nuanced exclusion of non-glacier areas like debris-covered regions. Automated systems may lack this level of precision and contextual understanding but could potentially process data faster.

Comparison.Question: How does the exclusion of debris-covered ice in glacier inventories affect the reported glacier area changes when using datasets like TPG compared to inventories that include debris cover?
Comparison.Answer: Excluding debris-covered ice, as done in the TPG datasets, results in a more accurate representation of net glacier area changes by focusing on debris-free ice. Inventories that include debris cover may report larger glacier areas but can introduce inaccuracies due to the difficulty in distinguishing debris-covered ice from surrounding terrain and other land features.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of multiple remote sensing data sources and interpretation techniques improve the accuracy of glacier mapping on the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing data sources, such as Landsat images, SRTM DEM, and Google Earth, along with various interpretation techniques like false-color composites and manual digitization, allows for more accurate glacier mapping by accounting for factors like mountain shadows and seasonal snow. This comprehensive approach helps refine glacier boundaries and ensures higher precision in data extraction, as evidenced by the half-pixel accuracy control (15m) achieved in the dataset.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are faced in distinguishing between debris-covered and debris-free glacier areas, and how might these affect the interpretation of glacier change data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in distinguishing debris-covered from debris-free glacier areas include the inability to remove debris-covered areas from certain inventories and the potential for snow and cloud coverage to obscure glacier delineation. These challenges can lead to discrepancies in glacier change data interpretation, as debris-covered areas might be misclassified or omitted, affecting the accuracy of area change assessments over time.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the temporal and spatial variability of climatic influences on the Tibetan Plateau impact glacier change data collected from remote sensing sources?
Interpretation.Answer: The temporal and spatial variability of climatic influences, such as the Indian monsoon in the southeast and westerlies in the west, can significantly impact glacier change data by causing variations in melt rates and seasonal snow coverage. These climatic factors contribute to the heterogeneous patterns of glacier shrinkage observed across the plateau, necessitating careful interpretation and potentially requiring adjustments in data collection and analysis methods to account for these environmental variables.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately delineating glacier boundaries in high-altitude regions using satellite imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors contributing to the challenges include the presence of snow and cloud cover, which can obscure glacier outlines, and the difficulty in distinguishing debris-covered ice from debris-free ice in satellite imagery. Additionally, spatiotemporal differences in climate variability and topographic effects can affect the accuracy of glacier delineation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variations in glacier shrinkage rates across different regions of the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in glacier shrinkage rates are caused by differing climatic influences across the plateau, such as the dominance of the Indian monsoon in the southeastern regions and the influence of the westerlies in the western areas. Additionally, the spatial gradient of glacier shrinkage rates, decreasing from the southeast to the north and west, reflects the interplay of these climatic factors with topographic features and hydrological units that either contribute meltwater to inland depressions or the ocean.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the results of excluding debris-covered areas from glacier datasets, and what implications does this have on the understanding of glacier dynamics?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding debris-covered areas from glacier datasets results in a more accurate representation of debris-free glacier changes. This omission, however, can lead to underestimation of total glacier mass loss and area change, which impacts the understanding of glacier dynamics, especially in regions where debris cover is significant.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of using Landsat satellite imagery and DEMs in collecting glacier data on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to accurately delineate debris-free glacier areas and understand their spatial heterogeneity over time. This approach is intended to provide a comprehensive inventory of glacier changes and enrich existing datasets with detailed comparisons, contributing to research on glacier shrinkage and water resource implications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of controlling data quality measures to within half a pixel in glacier boundary digitization?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to enhance the accuracy of glacier boundary data to a spatial resolution of 15 meters, which is critical for detecting subtle changes in glacier areas over time. This level of precision supports better assessments of glacier shrinkage rates and informs hydrological and climate change research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy of glacier boundary digitization in remote sensing datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The glacier boundaries are digitized manually with guidance from SRTM DEM v4.1 and Google Earth imagery. The process involves manual delineation on-screen from false-color image composites, followed by validation and editing by different operators overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps, and corresponding satellite images. The boundary accuracy is controlled within half a pixel (15m).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to integrate multiple data sources and methods for comprehensive glacier data extraction?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data extraction process involves using Landsat8 OLI satellite multispectral remote sensing data corrected and mosaicked into false-color composite images. The process references band ratio method results, SRTM DEM V4.1 data, Google Earth, and HJ1A/1B satellite images from different seasons. Non-glacier areas are excluded by comparing with previous glacier inventories and expert knowledge.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the extraction of accurate glacier boundaries from multispectral remote sensing imagery?
Enablement.Answer: Based on the field information, data processing techniques such as geometric and radiometric correction of Landsat8 OLI multispectral data, and the creation of false-color composite images (RGB:654), enable the extraction of accurate glacier boundaries. These techniques, combined with manual visual interpretation, SRTM DEM data, and cross-referencing with Google Earth and additional satellite imagery, help exclude non-glacier areas like mountain shadows and seasonal snow.

Enablement.Question: What methodological approaches enable researchers to control data quality during glacier boundary digitization?
Enablement.Answer: Methodological approaches that enable data quality control include manual digitization with repeated validation and editing by multiple operators, ensuring glacier boundary precision within half a pixel (15m). This process involves overlaying digitized outlines onto several reference sources, such as Google Earth imagery and topographic maps, to verify accuracy.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges when using satellite imagery for glacier inventory in regions with high cloud cover, and how might these be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: Expected challenges include difficulty in distinguishing glaciers from clouds, which might be addressed by selecting high-quality images with minimal cloud coverage and employing techniques like false-color composites to enhance ice and snow differentiation, as indicated by the methods utilizing different band combinations for image analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the effectiveness of using multispectral remote sensing data for glacier area delineation on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multispectral remote sensing data, such as Landsat8 OLI, is effective for glacier area delineation on the Tibetan Plateau. It enables the creation of false-color composite images that aid in distinguishing ice and snow from clouds. However, the process requires careful manual digitization to ensure accuracy, especially in complex terrain where debris cover and seasonal snow may affect results.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the challenges in achieving accurate glacier data extraction in regions with frequent cloud cover and snow, such as southeastern Tibet?
Judgmental.Answer: Achieving accurate glacier data extraction in regions with frequent cloud cover and snow, like southeastern Tibet, is quite challenging. The presence of clouds and snow can obscure glacier outlines, making it difficult to ensure precise delineation. Selecting high-quality images with minimal cloud and snow coverage and using techniques like manual digitization and validation against multiple data sources are crucial to overcoming these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: In your judgment, what are the potential benefits and limitations of integrating multiple datasets, such as SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery, for enhancing glacier boundary accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple datasets like SRTM DEM and Google Earth imagery can significantly enhance glacier boundary accuracy by providing additional topographic and visual context. This integration allows for cross-validation and error checking, improving the reliability of the delineation. However, it may also introduce complexity and require considerable expertise to effectively manage and interpret the different data sources.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure how the manual digitization of glacier outlines can ensure accuracy across different operators and time periods.
Assertion.Answer: The manual delineation was carried out by three operators over a period of 6 years. The delineated glacier outlines were validated and edited by different operators at least three times by overlaying them onto Google Earth imagery, DEMs, topographic maps, and corresponding satellite images by another two glacier researchers with field survey experience.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data processing methods used in collecting glacier data from satellite imagery in high-altitude regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing methods for collecting glacier data involve using Landsat8 OLI satellite multispectral remote sensing data, correcting and mosaicking to create false-color composite images (RGB:654). Manual visual interpretation, supported by the band ratio method results, is employed. This process includes referencing SRTM DEM V4.1 data and images from Google Earth and HJ1A/1B satellites from different seasons of the same year to mitigate shadow and seasonal snow effects. Non-glacier areas such as steep cliffs and bare bedrock are excluded, and glacier boundaries are digitized with a precision of half a pixel (15m). This multi-source, multi-method, expert-interactive approach results in more accurate mountain glacier data extraction.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in removing debris-covered areas in glacier inventories and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A significant challenge in removing debris-covered areas in glacier inventories is the inability to distinguish debris cover from debris-free ice, as observed in the GAMDAM inventory. Snow and clouds also affect glacier delineation, particularly in regions with frequent cloud cover, such as southeastern Tibet. A potential solution could involve using higher resolution imagery or multispectral data to improve differentiation between ice and debris. Additionally, integrating various temporal satellite images and employing advanced image processing techniques, like machine learning, could enhance the accuracy of identifying debris-covered glaciers.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose methods to improve the accuracy of glacier delineation in satellite imagery, considering the challenges of cloud cover and seasonal snow.
Request/Directive.Answer: To improve the accuracy of glacier delineation in satellite imagery, methods could include using a combination of high-resolution images from different seasons to reduce cloud cover and seasonal snow interference. Advanced image processing techniques, such as machine learning algorithms designed for pattern recognition, can further aid in distinguishing glaciers from clouds and snow. Incorporating ground control points and topographical data from sources like SRTM DEM can enhance geometric accuracy. Additionally, employing a collaborative approach where multiple operators validate and edit delineated outlines can ensure higher precision and reliability in the final glacier data.
